trans-unit.source: Reverse DNS records are used in a variety of situations.
trans-unit.target: Reverse DNS records are used in a variety of situations.

trans-unit.source: Server validation and authenticating server requests among them.
trans-unit.target: Server validation and authenticating server requests among them.

trans-unit.source: For example, reverse DNS records are widely used in combating e-mail spam by verifying the sender of an e-mail message by verifying its reverse DNS record, and also, if that host was recognized as authorized to send e-mail from the originating domain.
trans-unit.target: For example, reverse DNS records are widely used in combating e-mail spam by verifying the sender of an e-mail message by verifying its reverse DNS record, and also, if that host was recognized as authorized to send e-mail from the originating domain.

trans-unit.source: Reverse DNS records, or PTR records, are DNS record types that enable the translation of a publically routable IP address back to a name.
trans-unit.target: Reverse DNS records, or PTR records, are DNS record types that enable the translation of a publically routable IP address back to a name.

trans-unit.source: In DNS, names such as app1.contoso.com, are resolved to IP addresses in a process that is called forward resolution.
trans-unit.target: In DNS, names such as app1.contoso.com, are resolved to IP addresses in a process that is called forward resolution.

trans-unit.source: With reverse DNS, this process is reversed to enable the resolution of the name given its IP address.
trans-unit.target: With reverse DNS, this process is reversed to enable the resolution of the name given its IP address.

trans-unit.source: For more information on Reverse DNS records, please see [here](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverse_DNS_lookup).
trans-unit.target: For more information on Reverse DNS records, please see [here](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverse_DNS_lookup).

trans-unit.source: How does Azure support reverse DNS records for your Azure services?
trans-unit.target: How does Azure support reverse DNS records for your Azure services?

trans-unit.source: Microsoft works with a number of registries to secure an adequate supply of publically routable IP blocks.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft works with a number of registries to secure an adequate supply of publically routable IP blocks.

trans-unit.source: Each of these blocks is then delegated to Microsoft-owned and operated authoritative DNS servers.
trans-unit.target: Each of these blocks is then delegated to Microsoft-owned and operated authoritative DNS servers.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft hosts the reverse DNS zones for all publically routable IP blocks assigned to it.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft hosts the reverse DNS zones for all publically routable IP blocks assigned to it.

trans-unit.source: Azure enables you to specify a custom fully-qualified domain name (FQDN) for public routable IPs assigned to your deployments.
trans-unit.target: Azure enables you to specify a custom fully-qualified domain name (FQDN) for public routable IPs assigned to your deployments.

trans-unit.source: These custom FQDNs will then be returned for reverse DNS lookups for those IPs.
trans-unit.target: These custom FQDNs will then be returned for reverse DNS lookups for those IPs.

trans-unit.source: Azure provides reverse DNS support for all publically routable IPs at no additional cost, and for services deployed using the classic and ARM deployment models.
trans-unit.target: Azure provides reverse DNS support for all publically routable IPs at no additional cost, and for services deployed using the classic and ARM deployment models.
